The violence and intimidation we’ve seen today undermines the very objectives of a free and functioning Republic and has absolutely no place here.

A number of Capitol Police have taken the brunt of the violence. Please continue to keep them and their families in their prayers.

Getting word that we will soon be convening to continue our work. I’m now getting a chance to review the video of what has been going on outside the Capitol & it is absolutely heartbreaking. We have inherited such a gift as Americans, and I am grieved by what we have seen today.

Thank you all who are praying for our nation’s capital at this time. 

We are safe, but please pray for our Capitol Police who are taking the brunt of this senseless violence.
These unilateral actions — not taken by the state legislatures but judges and election officials — are not supported by the Constitution. Therefore, I will object. 6/6

In many states, however, judges and election officials at varying levels instituted their own election processes. These new processes implemented, sometimes weeks leading up to Election Day, violated established state election laws. 5/6

Article II of the Constitution (reaffirmed in the 12th Amendment) makes clear that it is the state legislatures who define how electors are selected — in other words, how elections are managed within their state. 4/6

The Constitution establishes the framework upon which our Republic rests. The constitutional restraints on those in authority are not suspended in crisis — but are established, in part, to ensure that even in a crisis those authorities remain defined. 3/6

Three days ago, I once again took a solemn oath to 'support and defend the Constitution of the United States.' Today, I will be taking one of the most important votes in Congress regarding the Constitution and the Republic which rests upon it — certifying the election. 2/6

Today, I will act on my obligation to ensure a constitutional republic by objecting to those of the contested states which unconstitutionally usurped the authority of their state legislatures to govern the election. 1/6

- $14 million for the Kennedy Center

5/ In a brief moment of candor, Speaker Pelosi recently admitted to playing political games with these bills, proving she and Senator Schumer were not negotiating in good faith before the election.

With these new emergency savings accounts, individuals would be able to deposit and withdraw money from that account tax-free when they use it for qualified expenses, such as mortgages, rent, utilities, property taxes, child care, and health care. (4/6)

The first bill would provide individual taxpayers with the ability to save up to $5,000 per year by making tax-free contributions to an emergency savings account. A married couple would be able to save up to $10,000. (2/6)
